title: 113_s1484
content: The Act is titled the "Sabine National Forest Land Exchange Act of 2013" and includes definitions for various terms. The "Authority" in the Sabine National Forest Land Exchange Act of 2013 refers to the Sabine River Authority of Texas. The term "Federal land" includes National Forest System land within the Sabine National Forest and the Toledo Bend Project boundary in Texas. The Sabine National Forest Land Exchange Act of 2013 involves the exchange of Federal land with the Sabine River Authority of Texas. The Federal land includes National Forest System land within the Sabine National Forest and the Toledo Bend Project boundary. Non-Federal land refers to private land surface estate. The term "non-Federal land" refers to private land adjacent to Sabine National Forest owned or to be acquired by the Sabine River Authority of Texas and mutually agreed upon by the Secretary of Agriculture. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Agriculture, acting through the Chief of the Forest Service. The term "Toledo Bend Project" refers to the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission project numbered 2305. The term "wilderness area" is also defined. The term "wilderness candidate land" refers to the surface estate of land adjacent to the Indian Mounds Wilderness Area in Sabine National Forest, to be agreed upon by the Sabine River Authority of Texas and the Secretary of Agriculture. SEC. 3. LAND EXCHANGE, SABINE NATIONAL FOREST. In exchange for non-Federal land, wilderness candidate land, and any cash payment, the Secretary will convey all US interests in Federal land to the Authority, subject to existing rights. An appraisal of the land must be completed within 180 days of the Act's enactment. The Secretary must complete an appraisal of the surface estate of Federal land, non-Federal land, and wilderness candidate land within 180 days of the Act's enactment, following specific appraisal standards. The Secretary must appraise the Federal land, non-Federal land, and wilderness candidate land within 180 days of the Act's enactment, following specific standards. The value of the Federal land must consider any restrictions imposed by a restrictive covenant. The exact acreage and legal description of the land to be conveyed will be determined by a survey. Federal land, non-Federal land, and wilderness candidate land to be conveyed under subsection (a) will be determined by surveys or other means agreed upon by the Secretary and the Authority. Costs of the land exchange will be shared equally between the Authority and the Secretary. The exchange will be conducted on an equal value basis, and cash may be used to equalize the values of the land exchanged. The values of land exchanged may be equalized through a cash payment exceeding the statutory limit. Any cash payment received will be deposited into a fund and available for expenditure by the Secretary. Public Law 90-171 (Sisk Act) allows the Secretary to use funds for acquiring land to add to the National Forest System. The title of non-Federal land conveyed must meet the Secretary's approval and Attorney General's standards. The Sisk Act allows the Secretary to use funds to acquire land for the National Forest System, with the title of non-Federal land needing approval from the Attorney General. The deed conveying Federal land to the Authority must reserve any subsurface mineral estate owned by the United States, including oil, gas, rock, sand, and gravel, and include a restrictive covenant. The Secretary conveys Federal land to the Authority with a covenant that it must be used in a manner consistent with adjacent National Forest System or wilderness area land, remain unsubdivided, and not be used for commercial, residential, or industrial development. The covenant does not create any property interest. The Authority can operate Forest Service campgrounds conveyed under subsection (a) with authorization from the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission. Congress intends the land exchange to be completed within 1 year of the Act's enactment. SEC. 4. BOUNDARY ADJUSTMENT, INDIAN MOUNDS WILDERNESS AREA, SABINE NATIONAL FOREST. Boundary Adjustment: The Secretary will modify the boundaries of the wilderness area to exclude land within the Toledo Bend Project and include acquired wilderness candidate land. The Secretary will designate acquired wilderness candidate land as part of the wilderness area under the Wilderness Act, filing a map and legal description with the House Committee on Natural Resources and the Committee on Energy. The Secretary will file a map and legal description of changes to the wilderness area boundaries resulting from a land exchange with the House Committee on Natural Resources and the Senate Committee on Energy. The filed map and description will have the same legal force as if included in the Act, with the Secretary allowed to correct errors. The map and description will also be available for public inspection. The map and legal description of changes to wilderness area boundaries resulting from a land exchange will be filed by the Secretary with the House Committee on Natural Resources and the Senate Committee on Energy. Any errors in the map and description can be corrected by the Secretary. The map and description will be available for public inspection in Forest Service offices.
